subject: RE: [junit] Reporting more then 1 failed assertion per test

messageBody:
Regarding the following comment:

"I guess this whole discussion really boils down to what constitutes
a test. I choose to organize my tests so that I generally have one
test per tested method, with appropriately many asserts per test. "

I think it is best to keep methods as concise and as focused as
possible (see Refactoring by Fowler, et al; basically, your code will
be more reliable and easier to maintain). For me, this means writing
several small test methods for the method I am testing, and at most
having one assert per test method and sometimes no asserts at all
(for example, if you are testing an exception that passes control to
a catch block, there is no need to put assert(true) in the catch
block).

I haven't really followed the recent thread regarding "Why doesn't
JUnit count asserts", but I now understand the position of some
people who favor counting asserts. If you have many asserts in one
test method, counting asserts would give you the number of conditions
you have tested. However, I think it would be best to put each
specific condition in a seperate test method. I usually have between
eight and sixteen test methods for each method I am testing.

I use the following naming convention for my test methods to keep
things organized:

test_##_nameOfMethodBeingTested

For example, the eigth test method for the method isAccountAssigned
would be,

test_07_isAccountAssigned


--- Jason Rogers <jason.rogers@...> wrote:
> Point well taken, Tom, but I still disagree. I guess it is a
> matter of
> taste for the most part. However, I wouldn't like the framework to
> be
> 'polluted' by the counting of asserts - but maybe I am just being
> too
> dogmatic. Thanks for your well-formed opinions!!!
>
> -Jason

> > Jason Rogers wrote:

> > > I respectfully disagree. You assume that asserts and
> > test cases are equal
> > > in their importance. What I want to know is whether or
> > not a test has
> > > passed. ... So, why count asserts? Perhaps to give
> > > that warm, fuzzy feeling... perhaps for some other reason.
> >
> > The only important thing is whether the application
> > works. Whatever else we
> > evaluate, whether it is the number of asserts, the number
> > of tests, the number
> > of test cases, or even whether we test at all, is just
> > there to give us that
> > "warm, fuzzy feeling" or to give us the shivers. The
> > number of tests/asserts
> > doesn't prove anything but it does give us a hint at an
> > appropriate body
> > temperature.
> >
> > I guess this whole discussion really boils down to what
> > constitutes a test. I
> > choose to organize my tests so that I generally have one
> > test per tested method,
> > with appropriately many asserts per test. Other
> > programmers might want to
> > refactor my test code so that basically one assert per
> > test was the rule. This
> > is probably just a matter of taste. If so, it would be
> > nice if JUnit would
> > support both approaches - displaying the number of tests
> > _and_ the number of
> > asserts.
> >
> > - Tom
